postsData.name:
Daren Lauda
Daren Lauda
postsData.content:
I tried to get to New Orleans last week. I really did.

I wanted to attend the Pavilion CEO Summit in person, but like 90% of attendees, I didn't make it.

New Orleans isnâ€™t equipped to handle 10â€ of snow. So, the event went virtual. And I still learned.

Some of the data presented was more troubling than the weather.

1). The revenue growth rate for SaaS business has been cut in half since the summer of 2021.
2). SaaS go-to-market efficiency is on the decline.
3). Top SaaS stocks are surging, but start-ups face more significant challenges.
4). Down rounds are â€œback on the menu.â€
5). In 2024, more startups closed than in the previous four years (2020 to 2023).

But there was good news.

1). The worst of layoffs are thought to be behind us.
2). The number of down rounds is declining.
3). VC deal volume is still well below years prior but showing signs of rebound.
4). Startup M&A is nearing record highs.
5). Profitable, efficient growth is the new normal.

And, if you havenâ€™t heard, AI is a pretty big deal.

Overall, I left the event feeling bullish.

The path to startup success in SaaS is more challenging than it used to be.

But the storm is ending. The signs are everywhere.

Heck, it is going to be 65 degrees in New Orleans today.

And I will be signing up to attend again next year. The CEO Summit is my favorite event of the year.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Despite the challenges, its encouraging to see signs of recovery in SaaS. Excited for whatâ€™s ahead! ğŸŒŸ #SaaS #Leadership

postsData.name:
Sally Mildren
Sally Mildren
postsData.content:
Thereâ€™s a saying that relates mostly to betting or investments to not â€œchase your lossesâ€. ï¸ I used to watch my elderly mom do that at the casino, convinced a higher bet would get her money back. It rarely worked out.

But, Iâ€™ve had to learn this concept in business too.

Case in point, I ignored my gut and bought that service I knew I wasnâ€™t ready for. It was a significant investment, a stretch for where I was, and I should not have done it. Deep down I knew.

And as a business owner or entrepreneur, you will make some decisions that donâ€™t pan out how you thought. Or are no longer serving you. Sometimes they are just wrong. Shiny objects and slick sales tactics will get you to believe you need saving and that they will make your business dreams come true. ï¸

If you made the same mistake I have, learn from it and move on. Nothing is bringing that money back. Donâ€™t keep chasing losses.

The real lesson is that you know. Trust yourself. Listen to your gut and move quickly if youâ€™ve made a mistake. Donâ€™t pay monthly fees for something that is not for you or not working!

Whether that is a software, vendor or consultant. Stop Chasing Losses!
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Trusting your instincts is key in business. Every setback is a lessonâ€”letâ€™s focus on growth and move forward! ğŸš€

postsData.name:
Eugene Krasicki
Eugene Krasicki
postsData.content:
4 Essential Tips for Founders to Navigate Growth

1. Define Your Vision Clearly

A strong vision aligns your team and attracts the right partners. Be specific about what success looks like and communicate it often to keep everyone focused on long-term goals.

2. Learn to Say No

Not every opportunity is worth pursuing. Prioritize tasks and projects that align with your core mission. Saying no to distractions allows you to stay efficient and focused on growth.

3. Build Relationships, Not Transactions

Invest time in creating genuine connections with customers, partners, and investors. People are more likely to support you if they feel valued and understand your mission deeply.

4. Be Data-Driven, but Stay Intuitive

Use metrics to guide your decisions, but trust your instincts when the numbers donâ€™t tell the whole story. Balancing logic with intuition is key to spotting hidden opportunities.


Found this helpful? Share with your network and letâ€™s grow together!
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Defining your vision and building relationships are crucial for sustainable growth. Thanks for sharing these tips!

postsData.name:
Pooja Yadav
Pooja Yadav
postsData.content:
Why Value Matters More Than Time
Years spent in a position or a company might reflect experience, but they donâ€™t automatically equate to growth. Growth stems from:

Impact: Have your actions made a tangible difference?
Adaptability: Are you learning and evolving with changing times?
Innovation: Are you bringing fresh ideas and solutions to the challenges at hand?

The Myth of Tenure
Staying in the same place for years might provide stability, but it doesnâ€™t guarantee progress. A stagnant role can lead to complacency, where you mistake time for growth. True progress comes from pushing boundaries, taking risks, and stepping out of your comfort zone.

Ways to Focus on Value-Driven Growth
Prioritize Impact: Look for ways to contribute meaningfully. Measure your success by the difference you make, not the time youâ€™ve spent.

Seek Continuous Learning: Growth is rooted in learning new skills, adapting to change, and challenging yourself.
Embrace Change: Donâ€™t hesitate to explore new roles, industries, or opportunities if they allow you to add value and grow.

Remember:
Growth is a journey measured by progress, impact, and contributionsâ€”not by the clock. Instead of asking, â€œHow long have I been here?â€, ask, â€œWhat have I accomplished, and how have I made a difference?â€

Create, innovate, and add value every step of the way. Your legacy isnâ€™t tied to longevity; itâ€™s tied to significance.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Its the impact we make and the growth we pursue that truly define our careers. Lets prioritize value over tenure! ğŸš€

postsData.name:
Neil Sarkar
Neil Sarkar
postsData.content:
If you think closing a deal is hard, try navigating a maze blindfolded. Yeah, itâ€™s that kind of day.

Just Kidding 

So? A 12 months sales cycle?

Perfect! Just what I needed in life 

Said no one EVER !

I swear to god if I got a dollar for everytime I heard â€œWeâ€™ll circle back on thisâ€ Iâ€™d have enough money to fund my own manufacturing empire. CRAZY right? 

Donâ€™t you guys think that closing a manufacturing deal is like solving a rubiks cube while being on a roller coaster? 

You gotta navigate multiple stakeholders with different priorities, sales cycle dragging on a plot twist in a bad soap opera   and the communication gaps that makes you wonder whether you are speaking some kind of alien language which is different from everyone else .

Now Iâ€™ve been stuck in the trenches too and I have learnt a few things that has helped me survive this madness.

Allow me to jot that down for you: 

1ï¸âƒ£ Forget your product specsâ€”manufacturers care about downtime, inefficiencies, and cutting costs. Focus on solving THEIR problems.

2ï¸âƒ£ Youâ€™re not talking to one person. Youâ€™re talking to a team of conflicting interests. Speak CFO, engineer, and even "back-in-my-day" nostalgia if you have to

3ï¸âƒ£ Most deals die at the â€œWeâ€™ll think about it phaseâ€. Create urgency, but donâ€™t pull the sleazy "buy now" stunt. Link your solution to what THEY care about like meeting goals or keeping the boss happy.

4ï¸âƒ£ Most manufacturers donâ€™t like taking risks at first, so back up your pitch with proof. Case studies, success stories, and pilots arenâ€™t optionalâ€”theyâ€™re essential

Now yâ€™all must be wondering where doescome into the picture?

Let me tell you how: Our AI agents help manufacturers by taking up the more complex and time consuming task so that our clients can focus on what really matters i.e. building relationships, closing deals and driving growth.

No more getting stuck in endless approval cycles or fighting with spreadsheets. Just clear, simple data to cut through the corporate quicksand.

So, next time youâ€™re in a meeting with 12 decision-makers and zero decisions, remember this: closing deals isnâ€™t about luck. Itâ€™s about strategy, empathy, and the right tools to cut through the chaos. And if youâ€™re wondering where to find those tools, letâ€™s just say... I have an idea 

Until next time, happy deal-closing, and may your pipeline be ever in your favor!
postsData.commentAdded: Navigating the sales maze takes skill! Love your insightsâ€”especially the focus on urgency and understanding stakeholders. Cheers to smarter deal-making! ğŸš€

postsData.name:
Hartmut HÃ¼bner, PhD
Hartmut HÃ¼bner, PhD
postsData.content:
The hidden cost of AI: Passive thinkers, despite faster results. Hereâ€™s how to fix it.

Generative AI like ChatGPT is revolutionizing how we work and learn, allowing new levels of productivity. But hereâ€™s the problem: over-relying on AI risks is turning us into passive thinkersâ€”weâ€™re faster, but are we smarter?

A recent study, â€œBeware of Metacognitive Laziness: Generative AIâ€™s Impact on Learning, Motivation, and Performanceâ€, reveals 5 key lessons for leaders who want to build smarter teams, not just faster ones.

1ï¸âƒ£ AI boosts short-term results but not deep learning.

Generative AI simplifies inconvenient processes (like writing reports) but doesnâ€™t teach deeper understanding or problem-solving.
â†³ Tip: Use AI to create a draft proposal, but follow up with a collaborative review session to refine ideas and align on goals.

2ï¸âƒ£ "Metacognitive Laziness" is real.

Over-reliance on AI leads to less critical thinking, as users blindly accept AI outputs without questioning them.
â†³ Tip: Before adopting AIâ€™s suggestions, ask: Does this align with our goals? and Whatâ€™s missing?

3ï¸âƒ£ AI doesnâ€™t always spark motivation.

While AI can make tasks easier, it doesnâ€™t always excite people or foster long-term engagement in learning.
â†³ Tip: Challenge employees to use AI for task support but still drive discussions that spark genuine interest in problem-solving.

4ï¸âƒ£ Human + AI = the winning combination.

The best outcomes come when AI enhances human expertise, rather than replacing it.
â†³ Tip: Use AI to draft customer service responses, but, before that, let your team create the story.

5ï¸âƒ£ Self-regulation is the secret weapon.

Without skills like goal-setting and reflection, AI can become a crutch instead of a catalyst.
â†³ Tip: Encourage teams to set learning goals and reflect weekly on how AI tools are helpingâ€”or not helpingâ€”them grow.

How to Balance AI and Critical Thinking in Your Organization

1ï¸âƒ£ Model Smart AI Use
â†³ Show your team how you balance AIâ€™s speed with human judgment.

2ï¸âƒ£ Build Reflection Routines
â†³ Integrate post-project reviews to evaluate what workedâ€”and what didnâ€™t.

3ï¸âƒ£ Train for Synergy
â†³ Teach employees to combine AI output with creativity and critical thinking.

4ï¸âƒ£ Encourage Collaboration
â†³ Blend AIâ€™s insights with team discussions for better decision-making.

5ï¸âƒ£ Empower Ownership
â†³ Involve teams in deciding how AI fits into workflows to build trust and accountability.

ï¸ Share this post with someone who wants to unlock smarter, not just faster, teams!

 Followfor actionable insights on AI, innovation, and leadership.
 Subscribe to The Flow Factor for weekly strategies to drive your business forward (Link in Profile).
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Balancing AI with critical thinking is key to fostering innovation and deeper learning in our teams. Lets challenge the status quo!

postsData.name:
Cliff K. Locks
Cliff K. Locks
postsData.content:
Inspiring the next generation to embrace innovation is not just about shaping their futureâ€”it's about securing ours. As leaders, mentors, and changemakers, we have the responsibility to guide todayâ€™s youth toward discovering their potential and fostering creativity. Whether itâ€™s through nurturing curiosity, teaching problem-solving, or celebrating diverse ideas, we can empower them to think big and dream even bigger.

This repost highlights the incredible role of innovation in transforming industries and the importance of protecting intellectual property. By engaging with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) and similar organizations, we can motivate young minds to become inventors, entrepreneurs, and leaders. postsData.content:
Weâ€™ve all felt that knot in our stomach.

The moment when you know you need to speak up, but fear holds you back.

These are the words that haunted me after every meeting.

â€œThis Conversation Is Going in Circles.â€

I watched the same points repeat like a broken record. Part of me wanted to say, â€œCan we take a breath and focus on real solutions?â€ But I was scared of sounding rude. Now I know a timely reset can save everyone from frustration.

â€œI Disagreeâ€”Hereâ€™s Why.â€

I had legitimate concerns but stayed silent, fearing backlash or appearing difficult. In hindsight, disagreement (with respect) sparks better ideas. The cost of silence? Missed innovation.

â€œIâ€™m Not Sure I Understand.â€

Nodding along was easier than risking embarrassment. But confusion doesnâ€™t vanish by pretending. If I had just asked for clarity, others would have breathed a sigh of relief too.

â€œWeâ€™re Avoiding the Real Issue.â€

We tiptoed around the elephant in the room, dancing around tough questions. By avoiding hard truths, we built shallow consensus. Speaking up might have felt uncomfortable, but it wouldâ€™ve led to genuine progress.

â€œHow Do We Make This Meeting Worth Our Time?â€

Deep down, I wanted to ask why we were all gathered, burning precious hours. Thereâ€™s power in questioning the status quo and refocusing on outcomes that truly matter.

â€œI Appreciate Everyoneâ€™s Input, But Letâ€™s Get Real.â€

The room was filled with safe, polite statements. Sometimes, we crave permission to be brutally honest. I wish I had given itâ€”because real growth starts when masks come off.

â€œIâ€™m Afraid to Speak Upâ€”But I Care Too Much Not To.â€

Honesty is scary. Yet silence slowly erodes our sense of purpose. When we speak from a place of genuine care, even tough feedback can strengthen a team rather than tear it apart.

Itâ€™s Time to Say What Matters

Meetings shouldnâ€™t drain our energyâ€”they should move us forward. If youâ€™re tired of walking away with regrets, speak up next time. Ready for more insights on meaningful communication? Sign up for my free newsletter.

DeepSeek: A Game-Changer in AI Innovation? 

Chinaâ€™s DeepSeek R1 model is proving that scarcity breeds creativity.  Despite restrictions on advanced AI chips like Nvidiaâ€™s H100, DeepSeek has delivered an impressive open-source multimodal AI model at what it claims is just 3-5% of the cost of its rivals.

 Key Takeaways:
1ï¸âƒ£ Cost Efficiency: DeepSeek reports training its model for $5.6Mâ€”far less than the $100M-$1B cost of U.S. counterparts like Anthropic and OpenAI.
2ï¸âƒ£ Impressive Results: Rated among the top 10 AI models globally, R1 performs similarly to OpenAIâ€™s advanced models and excels in search functionality.
3ï¸âƒ£ Optimizing Resources: By leveraging less powerful Nvidia H800 chips, DeepSeek shows how innovation thrives under constraints.

Even U.S. tech leaders are taking notice. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella called it â€œsuper impressiveâ€ and warned the industry to take Chinaâ€™s advancements seriously.
 Whatâ€™s your take on how resourceful innovation like this impacts the global AI race?

What part of your businessâ€”or your lifeâ€”needs to feel like a startup again?

As we start the new year, I notice some of my clients feeling a bit stagnant. This is the time for rethinking processes, challenging long-standing assumptions, and fostering a culture where asking bold, disruptive questions is encouraged. Not every issue will be solved by startup thinking, but where might it be useful for your team? Where should you look? Startups are fueled by energy, creativity, and a willingness to take risks. Itâ€™s a mindset of asking bold questions, embracing uncertainty, and chasing growth without fear of failure.

Where in your businessâ€”or your lifeâ€”can you embrace a startup mindset?

Warren Berger is an expert on innovation and creativity. In A More Beautiful Question, he explores the power of inquiry to unlock breakthrough ideas and foster innovation. The book encourages readers to ask deeper, more meaningful questions to reimagine possibilities and drive change.
